awd_titl_txt: Molecular Mechanisms of Stomatal Carbon Dioxide Signal Transduction in Plants
awd_abstract_narration:
Specialized pores (called stomata) in the leaves of plants open and close to regulate the uptake into plants of carbon dioxide from the air, and the loss of water (as vapor) from plant tissues out into the air. The opening and closing of stomata is regulated by signals that include the concentration of carbon dioxide in the air, but knowledge of how this is achieved is incomplete. This project will define the genes, proteins and networks of control involved in the regulation of stomata by carbon dioxide, and develop the knowledge necessary for the breeding of plants with improved growth properties and water use efficiency. The ability to manipulate these properties of plants is important for unfavorable weather conditions, climate changes, droughts becoming more frequent in some locations, and as carbon dioxide levels in the air increase. The investigators will pursue an outreach program involving research internships, professional preparation and mentoring with the public Preuss School for disadvantaged high school students in San Diego County as well as engaging with summer research interns from Howard University. Project personnel will be active within the San Diego Science Festival, a large annual event that brings science and innovation close to the public.

Some components (including carbonic anhydrase, anion channels and protein kinases) of the carbon dioxide signaling network that regulates stomatal aperture are known. However, the manner in which diverse signals, genes and proteins (a number of which are still to be uncovered) are integrated by guard cells into the network that controls stomatal aperture is not known. This project will use a combination of systems biology, biochemical, genetic and mathematical modeling approaches to identify additional critical molecular components of the signaling network and gain insight into the manner in which this network operates in guard cells to regulate stomatal aperture and how plants can improve their water use efficiency and drought resilience.

This award is supported jointly by the Cellular Dynamics and Function program in the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences and by the Physics of Living Systems program in the Division of Physics.

Project Outcomes Report

 

Intellectual Merit: 

Thousands of small adjustable pores, the stomata, are found in the epidermis of all plant leaves. Each stomatal pore is formed by a pair of guard cells. Stomata regulate the diffusion of carbon dioxide (CO2) into leaves for photosynthetic carbon fixation that is required for plant growth. At the same time stomatal pores control over 90 % of water loss by plants. A network of signal transduction mechanisms sense and transduce [CO2] changes to regulate stomatal apertures for optimization of CO2 influx, water loss and plant growth under diverse conditions. Photosynthesis and respiration cause large daily CO2 concentration (Ci) changes in the airspaces inside leaves. Moreover, atmospheric [CO2] is predicted to double during this century and this continuing [CO2] rise reduces stomatal pore apertures of plants. This will have profound effects on global gas exchange, water use efficiency of plants and heat stress resistance of plants. However, relatively little was known about the cellular, molecular, genetic and biophysical signaling mechanisms that mediate CO2 control of stomatal conductance in plants.

 

Important advances were made in understanding CO2 signal transduction mechanisms in the regulation of stomatal closing and opening funded by this NSF grant. This project investigated new working hypotheses and identified CO2/bicarbonate signaling and sensing mechanisms in guard cells that function in carbon dioxide-induced stomatal closing.

 

The CO2 and/or bicarbonate sensors that control stomatal movements remained unknown. Functional multi-component reconstitution of carbon dioxide/bicarbonate signaling using heterologous expression systems was used to investigate candidate bicarbonate-regulated proteins that mediate the carbon dioxide/bicarbonate response. This research pointed to the hypothesis that the SLAC1 anion channel might be one of the CO2 sensors in plant guard cells. Mathematical CO2/bicarbonate interaction modeling and model-guided experiments have aided in dissecting CO2 signal transduction mechanisms. Molecular dynamics modeling of the SLAC1 S-type anion channel aided in identifying an important site within the SLAC1 channel that we found is required for CO2/bicarbonate regulation of the SLAC1 anion channel and for high CO2-triggered stomatal closing. This research suggests that the SLAC1 channel is a secondary CO2/bicarbonate in guard cells, and identification of the primary sensor remains to be accomplished.

 

The above research further suggested that unknown upstream protein kinases are likely essential for CO2-triggered stomatal closing. Using a combination of genetics, biochemical, electrophysiological and physiological approaches, we identified the MPK12 and MPK4 MAP kinases as essential for CO2 control of stomatal closing.

 

Our research investigated and characterized an unexpected convergence mechanism by which CO2 signal transduction merges with the drought stress-triggered pathway that mediates control of stomatal movements. This research indicates that these responses can, in first order, be engineered to optimize plant growth while minimizing water loss.

 

We further developed a new forward genetics screening platform, that is now enabling screening of overlapping homologous gene functions on a genome-wide scale. We are using this platform and have made it available to the wider scientific research community through the Arabidopsis Biological Resource stock Center (ABRC).

 

Several additional important advances were made in identifying and characterizing new CO2 signal transduction mechanisms that have enhanced our understanding of this important response and a commentary on this area of present interest was prepared and published.

 

In summary, this research has provided models, genes, mechanisms and working hypotheses for future elucidation of the signaling network by which the presently continuing increase in atmospheric CO2 concentration will affect plant gas exchange between plants and the environment.

 

Broader Impacts:

Elucidation of the molecular mechanisms and network by which CO2 modulates stomatal conductance is fundamental to understanding the regulation of gas exchange between plants and the atmosphere, will help predict effects of atmospheric CO2 elevation on plants and can also contribute to future engineering of leaf heat stress avoidance and enhanced water use efficiency in selected crop plants and plant carbon sinks in the face of the continuing [CO2] rise and weather variability. The PI’s University has submitted patent applications on aspects of this research, one of which was approved.

 

Both PIs pursued outreach efforts through research training, internships and preparation of under-represented high school students. Furthermore, the PIs gave presentations to school students, trained under-represented high school students and undergraduate students in independent research projects, and worked to offer and expand high school student university internship offerings. The PIs prepared a manuscript with undergraduate students for the public on the subject of the impacts of rising CO2 on crop water use efficiency and food security. The PI was active within the San Diego Science Festival, a large annual event that is bringing science and innovation close to the public. In addition, both PIs trained and prepared postdoctoral, graduate scientists, Masters student and undergraduate students for advanced independent careers in research, industry, technology and science education.
